maybe dusting the inside with a fine layer of powdered sugar? The "grooves" in the mold (which end up being the area between grooves of the record) get filled with the powdered sugar, which will melt and harden from the heat of the candy syrup, which still gives you your "hills" between the grooves of the actual record, but keep air from building up in those smaller areas as the candy cools.

Similar idea to how perfectly clean water actually never boils (though it will evaporate) when heated, it needs imperfections for air bubbles to form around.

Theoretical fix idea for removing bubbles during casting.
Step 1: Build a vacuum chamber large enough to house the silicone mold.
Step 2: ...you see where I'm going with this.

There might be some engineering issues that come up, such as heat transfer in a (near) vacuum, the candy sticking to the vacuum chamber walls and breaking off through the new record during retrieval, or even just technical challenges building a new chamber. Even if it doesn't work completely, it should work at least a bit to remove bubbles. Probably line the walls with wax paper or grease them in some way to prevent the candy from sticking and potentially ruining the test. Straight box or cylinder with no neck to the lip, possibly an acrylic tube if you could get one that's crazy large, or even a five gallon bucket; use your best judgement, I have faith.
I figure that if you can get it to work well enough it would make for a pretty great episode, especially if you do run into problems but pull through in the end; Hero's Journey and all that.

this is what I found while doing some research on the subject:


Silicone molds are 'micro-porous' thus there is a bit of air trapped in the materials nooks-n-crannies (this is what helps make them non-stick).

When the hot sugar hits the mold the air is trapped between the cooling sugar and the mold wall. As the air warms up it expands and creates the bubbles.


There is also the inherent bubbles in the sugar.


Step 1: cure your mold in a pressure chamber or pressure pot.
Step 2: try isomalt instead of sugar
Step 3: heat your sugar solution to hard crack. Take off the heat for 5 minutes then put the pan in a 250 degree oven for a while to let the air bubbles rise and escape without losing too much heat.

Look into making glass candy (crystal clear sugar without any bubbles) for it, and do larger pretests more similar to what you want from the mold to make sure you'll get the results you want, heat up the mold and let mold and cool them together. One of the big secrets to glass candy, do not stir it, it'll cause the the sugar to crystalize wrong, which is part of what's causing the bubbles. Also, looking at DIY tanghulu and hard candy gems, since one is basically covering something (totally fruit) in glass candy (tanghulu), and the other is filling a mold with it (hard candy gems). Isomaly is actually wonderful for glass candy, due to it not turning a yellow color when it is heated to high temperatures, and standing up to humidity better than sugar, it's also a vegan and diabetic friendly. I have a small passion for candy making, so I hope this helps if you read it ^^.

If you put it in a large autoclave or just some positive pressure chamber, the bubbles would collapse to practically nothing as well as overcoming any surface tension on the candy that is stopping it from taking the shape perfectly. I suspect that is happening to you now since the player couldn't follow the grove very well. The other option would be to switch candy recipes to something with less surface tension.

Instead of pouring in the center of your record and having it spread outwards, try pouring a line from the center to an outer edge then work the silicone or candy out from that line all the way around around the record. This should leave less air pockets trapped in the grooves and impro fidelity. In other words, you spread the silicone and candy perpendicular to the grooves in your attempt, try spreading the silicone and candy parallel to the grooves next time.
